body: So you stick with the inkscape solution to convert to pdf?
strange, I still don't see any tests included in this PR ;)

Please leave the transformers and filters keywords at least to the base
Exporter class.
Not all function can be imported, and you might want to generate your
filters/transformers on the fly.

It does not prevent to also use dotted object name though.

Le jeudi 11 juillet 2013, Paul Ivanov a écrit :

> strange, I still don't see any tests included in this PR ;)
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/3607#issuecomment-20792049
> .

> ... public register_filter and register_transformer ...

True.. if they are public now, it's fine with me then.

Something like this 

```
#Create the exporter
exporter_instance = exporter_type(**kw)

#Try to convert the notebook using the appropriate conversion function.
if isinstance(nb, NotebookNode):
    output, resources = exporter_instance.from_notebook_node(nb, **kw)
elif isinstance(nb, basestring):
    output, resources = exporter_instance.from_filename(nb, **kw)
else:
    output, resources = exporter_instance.from_file(nb, **kw)
return output, resources
```

Ok, I had a quick read-through. Still not convinced about storing the converted figures in their mimetype in the cell-output, and about storing all figures, binary and not in the same resource dict.

We can discuss that on hangout.

Looks nice, otherwise, haven't dived into the writers though.

All of the changes we talked about should be checked in.  I'll work on an overview of how this all works and open a PR against the docs so people will know.  In addition, there is an example repository which I'm going to fill with examples, https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert-examples (right now only one exists)

Sorry, really busy but will review. Just one comment on the nice diagram.
the "resource" arrow seem to be "merged" into the notebook one. I think it would be preferable to have 2 side by side arrows. But that is just a detail.
@Carreau Thanks for the feedback on the diagram :smiley:  I thought no one noticed it.  I'll make the change when I log back into my windows partition.

OK, finally I got some time to see this one... I commented some few things because the others have already commented the same things I was thinking when I read the code... 
As I commented before, and you did that changes very quickly (thanks!), it is better to have all the default transformer in the base Exporter and then only enable the specific (and needed) transformers in each specific exporter (full_html, reveal, rst, etc). The code for the exporters now looks better and more understandable than before.
To resume, the PR look nice... I have to test some things about the Writer stuff (and go more deeper) to use it later with the reveal exporter, but overall it looks solid. Congrats @jdfreder and @ellisonbg, great work!
Other than a few docstrings and Application / Configurable bits to clean up, it's looking like the actual logic here is fairly complete.
:+1: to merge from me
:+1: I'm ready too, I have another PR that I'll open after this one that adds all of the accompanying tests...
Great! I want to begin with the writer stuff for the reveal exporter and some other css fixes for reveal and full_html, so :+1: to merge.
Matplotlib figures are not included in LaTeX. What am I doing wrong? Surely they are _supposed_ to be included...?

>  Matplotlib figures are not included in LaTeX. What am I doing wrong? Surely they are _supposed_ to be included...?

Looks like something broke, I'll see if I can figure out why.
:smiley: Should be fixed :+1: to merge

I still don't see figures in the LaTeX output (converted with pdflatex)
The .tex is generated inside the folder 'nbconvert_build', together with some .text files containing some of the text output of the cells. But still no figures to be found...

The .text should be deleted.
For pdflatex, the figures should be generated in PDF and included with \includegraphics{}

Did you update your branch?  The figures work for me using pdflatex, I'm using the example repository `https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert-examples`

Maybe when this PR gets merged you should open an issue if you still can't get it to work.

This is the command I use to convert notebook2 to latex pdf
 `ipython nbconvert --format="sphinx_howto"; cd nbconvert_build; pdflatex notebook2.tex`

OK, that works.
I was using --format="latex" (which seemed to me to be the obvious thing to write)...
It worked for notebook2. Not for my notebook, though. Let me work out what the problem is.

The figure in notebook2 does not get rendered as PDF, though, and is of low quality (PNG I guess).
For pdflatex the figures should by default be rendered in PDF. This does not seem to even be an option in nbconvert, looking at the source code? This needs to be added.

Still no luck -- absolutely no figure output.
My example file is here:

[odes_clean.ipynb](https://gist.github.com/dpsanders/d417c1ffbb76f13f678c)

It renders perfectly in nbviewer:

[NbViewer](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/d417c1ffbb76f13f678c)

I am at a complete loss as to what is happening...

One last question, what was the decision of the action of `ipython nbconvert` without arg ? `ipython nbconvert <a directory>`

I would like to re-discus the storing of figures/figuresnames in the resources dict.

All my comments remark can be done in another PR/post 1.0.

This is starting to be really big for review. so +1 for merging as is. 
This would need small changes to @jakevdp pelican plugin.
@dpsanders I'm not sure why the images are being output in html cells though...  I'll look some more
